document.text: WOODMAN CIRCLE MRS. FRANK P. GRAVES HELD ANNUAL PARTY Mi?. Mary Frances Jefferson Graves. 88. widow of Frank Peyton Graves, died January 3 in a Staun ton hospital after an extended ill ness. Surviving are a daughter, Mary Graves, of Appomattox, and two brothers, O. F. Jefferson and 0. G. Jefferson, both of Roanoke. Funeral services were conducted from New Hope Baptist Church on Tuesday at 1100 A. M., by the Rev. J. P. Leitner. Interment was in the church cemetery. Active pallbearers were Milton L, Hudson, H. A. Tor rence, Harry Ferguson, Georee Ah- bitt, Sr. J. H. OBrien, A. B. Ab- bitt.

document.text: William Pitzer Gills, who died at his home, Locust Grove, Friday morning, was the son of James Thomas and Cornelia Terri 1 Pitzer Gills. Though jiorn in Buckingham county, he moved to Appomattox in his boyhood on account of the death of his father. He then made his home with his uncle, the late Will iam Gills, who for many years was treasurer of the the county. He at tended the first public school evei taught in this county, Judge David A. Christian being the teacher. Mr. Gills engaged in various aeti- ties until the infirmities or age made, it necessary for him to retire from, public life. He was a senool trus.et of Appomattox county also serving as clerk to the school board, man carrier on R. F. D. No. 2, employed at one time by the Norfolk and Wes tern Railway, besides managing his arm near Appomattox. He was a iason and a Woodman of the  orld, and a Democr t who was un- werving in his par loyaly. Fii nany-lyears he was a faithful dea- on of Liberty Baptist church and teacher in the Sunday School. The deceased was a man whose lie was marked by fidelity to prin- ple. His was a goodly heritage of u ture and Godliness from an an cestry distinguished in the early history of America. Those who came in con4act with him were impressed by the deep spirituality of his nature. t  The funeral took place Sunday afternoon at Liberty Baptist church The Rev. H. Frederick Jones, the pastor, and the Rev. William May- field Thompson, a former pastor, conducting the services. The choir ,f the church sang Mr. Gills favor ite hymn, Rock of Ages. Tenny sons immortal poem, Crossing the Bar, was read and played on the pipe organ as a processional. Inter ment took place in the family plot in Liberty Cemetery, that part of the service. being conducted by the Masonic order. A host of friends and acquaintances, with many beautifa floral tributes attested to the love and high regard in which Mr. Gills was held in Appomattox and through out the state. Ihe active pallbearers were A. T. Inge, C. S. McDeormon, R. L. j Burk?, A. R. Harwood, J. C David son, N R. Featherston, B. G. An derson, Luther J. Morris. Honorary pallbearers included R. B. Hudgins, J. H. Lucado, T. W. Moses, Charles T. Moses, Pat Chand ler, L. Crawley, C. W. Smith, W. Stratton Taylor, Jennings Ferguson. T. Ed Owen, W. J. LeGrand, Dr. D. A. Christian, Dr. C. G OBrien, S L. Ferguson, Jr., J. H. OBrien, W. B. Caldyell, F. L. Murphy, E. VR-y Smith, Andrew Wingfield, H. C. Pul iam, Uoel Flood, Don Moses, John T. Cole, J. W. Caw son, John A. Iweedy, R. W. S an- ey, H. M. Burge, R. Travis Lee, F. A. OBrien, R. Edward OBrien, VV. W. OBrien, T. H. Inge, M. C. Imith, S. Guy Smith, R. C Wagner, J. A. Burke, Charlie Johnson, Pit zer Johnson, William Burke, D. A. Conner, D. E. Turnes, Jesse L. Tumes, James W. Caldwell, Harry Jenkins, Leonard Carter, E. Percy Sea, Odel! Howerton, Edmund H. Cawthorn, O. Cleveland Paulette. T. Morton Rosser, R. W. Smith, Leslie N. Ligon, L. E. Smith, C. N. Abbitt, J R Horsley, J. E. Chick, W. L. Brown, L. F. Ferguson, O P. Farrar, J. H. Cheatham, Dr. L L. Gayle, Dr. C. F. James, Robert Hubbard, Fitz Martin, Calvin H. Robinson, George F. Abbitt, Jr., T. W. Ferguson, Lester B. Harvey, J. D. Plunkett. Mr. Gills was first married to Miss Ella Pittman, who died some years ago. Two of the children of this union survive him, Henry Pitzer Gills of Marion, Virginia, and Mr 3 . Luth er B. Pittman, of Richmond. His second wife, who survives him, was Miss Albertha OBrien Of this mar riage, six children wire torn, James, passing away in inf.-ncy. The five living are Professor Allen Gils, of Clarksville Miss Cornelia Kyle Gills, of Appomattox Shelby Ken- nard Gills, of Richmond Mrs. Will iam Haller Copenhaver, of Marion Mrs. R. Banks Frazier, of Richmond. He also leaves five grandchildren, Mrs. R. S. Simpkins, of Chrisians- burg, Va. Mrs. Allen B. Pearcy, of Bristol, Penn. Joseph Pitzer Gills, of Pulaski, Va., Eloise Ogden, and Mary Joan Gills, of Clarksville, Va., and one brother, James T. Gills, of Lynchburg, his only other brother being the late Edmond Ernest Gills, of Appomattox.  And death itself, to him, was but The wider opening of the door Tha had been opening, more and more, Through all his life, and nevei as stiut. . . .

D ear T imes A s Myrtle stated tha the ease of the two brothers was a serious affair, I think the best thing to be done 8 to give them a cure for love, that is for the one that will be rejected and as I have the best cure of the kind 1 ever saw I will send it for their benefit and any that may need it Take twelve ounces of dislike, oue pound of res olution. two grains of common sense two ounces of experience, and three quarts of cooling water of considera tion  sit over the gentle fire-of love, sweeten with the sugar of forgetful ness, skim with the spoon of melan choly, putin the bottle of the heart, and stop with the cork of a clean conscience. Let it remain and you will quickly find ease and be restored to your seuses. These things can be found .it the apothecary of the house of understanding in the street of prudence at the village of content ment next door to reason. Now dont you think this just splendid ? Myrtle is a very appropriate non de plume for that fair writer, as Myrtle will love absent or present, perfect or imperfect. But think Daisy altogether inappropriate, he is certainly no beauty and whQ ever saw a fellow al iunoceuce. What has become of the fair cor respondent of Ander 8 onville, we miss her many good letters. It cant be she is some ones little wife aud household duties take all her time. Mr. J. H. OBrien was visiting in this neighborhood last weeki Nr. OBrieu was mustered out of the 1st W. Va. Volunteer Infantry, stationed at Columbus, Ga., about a month ago, and he is now visiting his fattier, to the joy of bis many frieLds. We congratulate Mr, John Webb in the good fortune of getting him a wife. We are glad that he,,ionud out an old bachelors life was no good. Miss Hallie OBrieu is visiting her cousin. M ss Roberta Forbes this week, they will also visit Miss Forbes sister, Mrs. Ha ding, of Prince Edward. The families of Mr. John Forbes and Mrs. Samuel Forbes are in the measlesly grip. Many good wishes for the T imes . O line .

document.text: Well, well, lets see vhat there is to chronicle tonight? Whither, vaulted columnar ver nacular?    First, J. H. Cheatham had a birthday yesterday. He was down on the streets before 7 oclock doffing his sombrero in token of 68 birthdays. Yas sah. And Len Smith and W. M. Hancock had birthdays togeth er Chooseday . . . 69 I do bow- lieve.    Then, theres that fishing party of Tuesday. Our Col. Joel, E. T. Mitc.hell, J. H. OBrien, aided and abetted to- wit, wherewithal and whereas by Watkins Abbitt, garnered their earthworms and, hied away to Horseleys Pond, wherever that is. The Col. mussed up his shirt front with a sun perch. Cope teste, Father Darkleaf, et cafeteria.    Nfurthermore, theres the case of the right Rev. Lee. Hes dean of the colored parsons in Roanoke. Happened to be here attending court last week and when a pair of matrimonial- bound colored folks applied for a license said Rev. Lee was called in to do the honors right in the clerks office. Vo-do-de- o-do.    Theres something, it might be chronicled, whimsical about a bathrobe. Father Darkleafs favorite is one used for eleven years. Had several given me since I got thatbut my bones and joints dont feel right in em.    And orchids to Mother Bright- leaf. Shes twenty-seven cents on the blue inc side of our bud get for June. And keeps her ledg r like a veteran, she does. And I like the fare better than Delmonicos.    Oh yes, I forgot, the colored couples names were Perry Nathenial Brown and Annie Lee Mins. Thats the sort of a reporter I am .   and the parsons initials are W. E., since Im being downright accurate.    And folks, Im warning you, Mather Brightleaf is hot after back subscribers. And when I told her about the way folks wouldnt Subscribe for them selves but borrowed. their neighbors paper, she turned up her nose, she did and said, The stingy things. One subscriber on one of the routes this week said he had to put up with four families borrowing his Times- - Virginian. Scallions and ashes.    George Peery no doubt real izes hes gonna be the next governor, but hes taking no chances. Has a plaque on hijP office wall containing four-leaf  clovers, horse-shoes and a rab bits foot.    Lots of suckers will bet on on the big prize fight tonight. The only thing I ever bet on was when I called Mother Brightleafs bet that my mother didnt serve oatmeal for break fast. Proved it too, by heck.

document.text: weeks now Slates of delegates to district and state conventions were elected at a Democratic mass meeting last Fri day night at the court house. The meeting adopted two resolutions one endorsing Watkins M. Abbitt for renomination and re-election to Congress from the Fourth District, introduced by Calvin Robinson and one endorsing the record of United States Senator Harry F. Byrd, in troduced by C. W. Smith. Congressman W. M. Abbitt was present and addressed the meeting. Charles F. P. Crawley served as the presiding officer of the meeting and C. W. Smith served as secretary. The following delegates, instruct ed to vote as a unit, were named to the Fourth District Convention in Petersburg, May 24 J. A. Bingham, George Abbitt, Jr. G. T. Moses, Sr. G. B. Buchanan, J. H. document.text: week H. H. Caldwell, Jr. entered the lists for this office. Commonwealth Attorney It is presumed that the incumbent, G. F. Abbitt, Jr. will file and will be the only candidate. County Treasurer J. Garland Plunkett and Thomas T. Martin ape the announced candidates. David T. Robertson, the incum bent sheriff, was appointed to fill out the term of the late H. W. Mc Kinney, and four years ago won a full term. He was opposed in that election four years ago by Vernell Mitchell. Sheriff Robertson inform ed The Times-Virginian this week that he would be a candidate, and to date no other has announced. The two-way race for Commission er of the Revenue will find H. H. Caldwell, Jr. opposing the veteran incumbent, J. H. OBrien. Mr. Cald- will be making his first bid for public office. He is the son of H. H. Caldwell, of Route 3, Appomattox. He graduated at Appomattox High School in 1943 and entered the Navy as Aviation Cadet August 10 of that year. While in the service he took special courses at the Universities of South Carolina and Georgia. He served on the USS. Bismarck Sea, and was on same when the carrier was sunk by a Jap dive bomber at tack Feb. 23, 1945. He was among the rescued survivors. He entered V. P. I. in the fall of 1945, and re ceived his B. S. degree in 1949. He was president of the civilian student foody his senior year. Since he has been employed with American To bacco Co., Schaffer Pen Co., and since 1954 with Gary Steel Products Corp, Lynchburg, as assistant to the general sales manager..

document.text: Wayside, Jan. 4.- Mrs. F . A . OBrien, who was rushed back to Ljhe hospital last Thursday, is im proving slowly. Beryl Covington, who underwent an operation for appendicitis last Tuesday night is expected to return home Tuesday. Mr. and Mrs. R M Webb spent SBfiday with Mrs. R.fW.Morris. Those who called in the home of I F A . OBrien Sunday were Mrs. R W. Morris, Mr. and Mrs.R. M Webb, Miss Cornelia Gills, Mr. and Mrs. Banks Frazier, Mr. and Mrs J.H . OBrien and Mr. Graves. Mr. and Mrs. Boilte have moved into the cottage of Mrs. Mildred Alvis. Mrs. Alvii and Patricia have moved into the home of F. A. OBrien. document.text: Wayside, Dec. I.- The W. M. U. of New Hope Church met in the home of Mrs F. A.OBrien Friday for the day, and observed the week of prayer for foreign missions. In the afternoon they had a quilting. Mrs. Banks Frazier has returned from the hospital to the home of her mother, Mrs. W. P. Gills. Miss Geòrgie McFadden was rush ed to the hospital Thursday. Misses Jacqueline Alvis ani Alic-sc Covington, of Richmond spent the holidays here with their parents. Mary Alice Webb was the guest of Aliese Covington. They all attended the football game Thursday in Roanoke. .The many friends of Mrs. George F. Abbitt, Sr., were glad to see her at church Sunday, after au extend ed illness. Miss Annie Torrence, of Farmville spent the holidays in the home of Gus Tumes, and accompanied Mr. and Mrs. Turnes and family to Roan oke for the week-end. Miss Kate OBrien, of Farmville spent the holidays here. Mrs. Sarah Wayne has returned from Hartford, Conn., where she spent the holidays. Mrs. Omer Burnett and children, Miss Claudine OBrien and Wyatt OBrien spent the holidays in the home of J. H. OBrien. Mrs. Eral Morris is visiting in the home of Mrs. R. W. Morris. Mesdames R W. Morris, Eral Mor ris, E D. Patterson, Bessie Turnes and Margaret OBrien called in the home of Mrs. F. A. OBrien Mon day night. News has been received of the ill ness of Mrs. Sam Turnes, of neai Cullen.

document.text: Tuesday of this week, Sunset at Appomattox, a documentary film,, produced in Hollywood, had its pre miere before a blue ribbon list of dignataries in Lynchiburg. Nearly 200 saw the advance showing, and came away thrilled at the splendid reproduction of the events of April 9, 1865 at Appomattox. At a dinner at the Virginian Ho tel preceding the showing, Represen tative W. M. Abbitt was toastmaster. Fred Helsaibeck, vice-mayor of the City of Lynchburg, gave the invoca tion. Distinguished guests, including educators and historians, were intro duced. Major-General U. S. Grant, III, grandson of Ulyssis S. Grant, spoke briefly, praising the peace at Appomattox reuniting the na tion. Rev. Richard H. Lee, a kinsman of R. E. Lee, spoke in the same vein. William A. Hart, director of adver tising, E. I. DuPont Company, pro ducers of Sunset at Appomattox, told the story of how the film, was made. Conrad L. Wirth, Director, National Park Service, thanked the DuPont Company for this documen tary contribution. Sunset at Appomattox will be televised nationally on DuPonts Cavalcade of America program, over ABC network, Tuesday night, Oct. 20. We understand WLVA - TV, in Lynchburg carries this program at 730 P. M. Attending the luncheon and the Premiere ... from Appomattox were r Mr. and Mrs. W. M. Abbitt, Mr. and Mrs. Chas. T. Moses, Judge and Mrs. Joel W. Flood, Mr. and Mrs. H. A. Gurney, Mr. and Mrs. D. T. Robert son, Mr. and Mrs. George Abbitt, Jr. C. W. Smith, Mr. and Mrs. J. A. Burke, Mr. and Mrs. C. T. document.text: Tuesday, Nov. 8, is General Election day in Virginia, and a last minute effort is being made to get out a sizeable vote for Appomattox County. There are approximately 2,500 eligible voter in the county, but thus far there has been a min imum of interest, and the size of the actual vote is uncertain. To be elected are unopposed candi dates for the State Senate and the House of Delegates, and a slate of unopposed nominees for county of fices. Polling places will open at 6 A. M. and close at 6 P. M. There are ten precincts in the county. The candidates, all Democrats, are as follows For the State Senate, Chas. T. Moses. For the House of Delegates John B. Boatwright. For Commonwealths Attorney George Abbitt, Jr. For County Treasurer John G. Plunkett. For Commissioner of the Revenue J. H. OBrien. For Sheriff David T. Robertson. For Supervisor in Southside Dis trict F. L. Murphy. For Supervisor in the Stonewall District Otho W. Martin, Jr. For Supervisor in the Colver Hill District Richard Webb. For Justice of the Peace, South- side District Cree to be elected T. W. Moses, Mrs. Lucille S. Con ner and E. T Guill. The officials to be elected Tues day will take office in January. In appealing for a good turn-out of voters next Tuesday, the quality of the candidates listed and the im portance of the eounty maintaining a record for a large vote, were cited as reasons for everyone making an effort to cast their ballots.

document.text: The general election in Appomat tox county Tuesday was like the present war in E u ro p e.... it was All quiet on the front! With no contests, and only one candidate for county offices, -only 613 voters wont to the polls! There were over 1,800 eltg ble Viters. The total vote by precincts was as follows Court Home, 194 Cheatwood, 8 Chap, 22 Rocks, 25 Pamplin, 04 Walkers Church, 35 Clover Hill, 81 Agee, 47 Oakville, 50 Stonewall, 87. The total vote for the unopposed candidates was For state senator, Charles T. Mos es, 686. For home of delegates, John B. Boatwright 569.. For commonweaths attorney, W. M. Abbitt, 580. For county treasurer, R. L. Burke, 572. For commissioner of the revenue, J. H. OBrien, 568. For sheriff, H. W. McKinney 586. For supervisor Clover Hill dis trict, F . A . OBrien 181. For supervisor Southside district. , Don Moses, 214. For supervisor Stonewall district, T.E.Owen, 168.

document.text: Supervisors a n d county of ficials of Appomattox county met at the court house Tues-  day night of this week and agreed to a slashing of the county tax rate and salaries.j The tax-rate will be cut t 1.50 and salaries will be - duced 10 per cent, it fit. agreed. The present i levies run from 1.80 to 1.95. The reduction is expected to cause a bolstering of confidence locally and will be warmly wel comed by tax payers. No con certed demand for a reduction had been made by citizens, but the supervisors and county of f a l s felt that the cut was in .ine with steps already taken by several other counties. The supervisors also felt it best to act in advance of widespread dissatisfaction that might be forthcoming if theratewere not . educed and wisely averted any m a s s meetings of tax payers such as a number of other coun ies have experienced. Th i s act is expected to renew confi dence in the administration of county affairs, and cooperation -vill now be sought in an effort -o avoid drastic cut in upkeep jf roads and the conduct of the jchools. The- statement signed by county supervisors, follows To T h e Taxpayers of Appo mattox Count Realizing the financial con dition of the farmers and citi zens of our county, brought about by the drought of last year, a n d the unprecedented depression whichwe are pass ing, and small demand and low prices for all farm products, and while all of us now receive the lowest salary and compen sation allowed by state laws, but desiring to help relieve the tax burden of o u r people to some extent, hereby express cur willingness and voluntarily agree to accept a ten per cent cut in salary or compensation for the year beginning January 1st, 1932, and pledge ourselves to do everything possible to practice economy in the admin istration of the county affairs, so that the county, school and road levy m a y be reduced to the lowest possible figure. The above ten per cent does not ap ply to the County Treasurer or the Commissioner of the Rev enue, as the reduction in levy automatically reduces their compensation more than ten per cent. C. W. Smith, Clerk R. L. Burke, County Treasurer Jo el W. Flood, Commonwealth Attorney H. W. McKinney, Sheriff J. H. OBrien, Comr. of Revenue J. A. Burke, Supt, of Schools F. A. OBrien, Supervisor Don Moses, Super visor T. E. Owen, Supervisor E. LeRoy Smith, Chairman School Board ,T. J. Ligon, Member School Board j  o! Davidson, Member School Board. ,, 111 viw of the, foregoing, we iu undersififned members of th e Board of Supervisors, whose duty it is to make up the bud get and fix the levy bf the coun ty, desire to state that we wish to do everything we can to low- er the tax rate to t h e lowest possible figure, consistent with sound financing and safeguard ing the institutions of our coun ty. We are sure we can make a substantial reduction in the levy for th e next fiscal year, and agree to make the total levy 1.50 on the 100.00 for all purposes, thus reducing the taxes of the people approxi mately 12,450.00. We real ize this means a substantial cut in county affairs, road building, and length of school term. This includes a reduction in the sal aries and wages of everyone employed by the county, but we feel that an emergency exists , Continued on Page 4

document.text: sister Southern States, which had already seceded. The call went out for volunteers to defend the firesides of the Old Do minion. Appomattox County responded nobly. A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight. From 1870 to the present has been a period of rebuilding and achievement. From its creation the County has been served until now by the following Officers CIRCUIT JUDGESJudges G. A. Wingfield, J. D. Hors- rv, Sam Coleman, George J. Hundley, Robt. F. Hutcheson and Joel W. Flood. COUNTY JUDGESLewis Daniel Isbell, Henry T. Par-  rish and David A. Christian. TRIAL JUSTICEST. R. Horseley and L. F. Isbell, Crawford Jones, Edward Woodson, T. J. Thornhill, David A. Christian, W. C. Franklin, H. D. Flood, Samuel L. Ferguson, Joel W. Flood and W. M. Abbitt. SHERIFFSJoel Watkins, Geo. T.
